page.title: 04LYDFORD GORGE
page.content: The Gorge is a deep ravine that has been carved by the River Lyd over thousands of years.It is about 2.5 miles long and averages 80feet to 100 feet in depth. The National Trust owns the Gorge and every year up to 80,000 visitors come to see it.A Warden and his Assistant and three full time workers are employed and there are also three part time workers. Once there were outlaws, called the Gubbins,living in the Gorge,and before that,in Anglo-Saxon times,the Gorge was used as a defence against the Danes. There is a waterfall called "The White lady" at one end of the Gorge and among the rocks at the higher end is a deep whirlpool called "The Devil's Cauldron"
